column1: 1556766049-4199,https://www.amazon.com/Carnivorous-Carnival-Unfortunate-Events/product-reviews/0064410129/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_hist_5?ie=UTF8&reviewerType=all_reviews&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=1,Stephen  (JM) K.,Continues from where it left off,19-Oct-05,"This is the second installement in the disastrous series labeled ""A Series of Unfortunate Events"". Where as the first book introduced you to the main characters, Violet, Klaus, Sunny and Count Olaf and simple story setting, this one continues to excite as a few more characters are added. I won't explain the story, seeing there has been more than two hundred reviewers who have reviewed this book, but I will say one thing, ""The Baudelaires continue to stumble in more woeful situations."" That is, if they can find a way out. But Count Olaf is unpredictable. We already saw his elusiveness throughout the first book.The book has endless meanings of words, seeing that is a good thing for younger readers. That does not wreck the book, but it slows down faster and more older readers. The book does not revolve around violence, even though there is, by the end of the book, a senseless murder(which I won't describe for you for you have to find out for yourself). There is also a terrifying car crash, lying and backstabbing, and a rude repulsive villian, which you'd all expect from a horrible and sad novel. The novel generally fluctuates around the fact the Baudelaires parents are dead which is reminded by Lemony Snicket several times, but it's not the case for the entire series. The books get thicker book by book by book, but you wouldn't expect the Baudelaires parents would be dead while you were reading book 6,7,8,9,10 or 11, would you. There is more information as the books go along.

I'd read this book a long time ago, so I can't explain in detail the story. But one thing I can remember is a page full of ""never""s when Violet or Klaus(my memory is fuzzy) were fiddling with dangerous electrical appliances.The Baudelaires are smart and difficult to outwit so that's why there are additional volumes in ""A series of unfortunate events"". Klaus is good for he is good at researching, Violet is good because she can create inventions without the materials needed when in dangerous situations, and Sunny is good at biting(what can you expect of an infant baby?). Sunny's inproper english is hard to understand but lucky we've go Klaus or Violet or even Lemony Snicket to translate. I've read all except the new one, Book 12. The series so far, if your up to ""The Reptile Room"" or you've just finished reading ""The Reptile Room"", may have a simple plan or setting, but the books get more complicated with endless layers of clues, riddles, mysterious characters throughout the series, and more members of Count Olaf join. Characters die, or are mistaken to be dead as I've said before. Also, this being not the most influential unfortunate events book, but being a successful book by the name of Lemony Snicket, it could be the most favorite books even though the book isn't as time consuming as the others. It is quite straight forward than the others. Also in ""The Bad Beggining"" the picture at the end of the book shows a snake on the corner of the street on the picture. ""The Reptile Room"" deals with snakes.

The book doesn't end on a happy note, and Mr. Poe and other characters are as gullible as ever.",5.0 out of 5 stars,Next page?,https://www.amazon.com/Carnivorous-Carnival-Unfortunate-Events/product-reviews/0064410129/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_paging_btm_46?ie=UTF8&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=46&reviewerType=all_reviews

Well, the book is about three Baudelaire children who rich, but are orphans. Their parents died in a fire. They go meet Uncle Monty, their new guardian because they past guardians have failed them to keep them safe. Especially, their first guardian, Count Olaf. Uncle Monty is really nice to them.

I like this book because the author makes the story so interesting and makes you want to read it. Also the author will also describe a scene, so you could imagine the scene. For example, in the story there is: But he didn't. As the Baudelaire orphans stared at Count Olaf, the taxi drove back down the driveway and the children were alone with their nemesis, a word which here means ""the worst enemy you could imagine."" Olaf smiled at them the way Uncle Monty's Mongolian Meansake, would smile when a white mouse was placed in its cage each day for dinner. ""Perhaps one of you might carry my suitcase in his wheezy voice. ""The ride along that smelly road was dull and unpleasant and I am very tired.""  The thing I don't like about the book is that the author would write a hard word and write the definition. Such as, in the book it also has: Uncle Monty laughed again. ""It's a misnomer,"" he said, using a word which here means ""really bad name.""

My favorite part in the book is when they meet Stephano and noticed that is was Count Olaf. Every time they said that a person is Count Olaf, but dressed up in a disguise nobody believes them, but in the end, they are always right. They were all happy, but gets all sad.",5.0 out of 5 stars,Next page?,https://www.amazon.com/Carnivorous-Carnival-Unfortunate-Events/product-reviews/0064410129/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_paging_btm_50?ie=UTF8&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=50&reviewerType=all_reviews

1556766040-4155,https://www.amazon.com/Carnivorous-Carnival-Unfortunate-Events/product-reviews/0064410129/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_hist_5?ie=UTF8&reviewerType=all_reviews&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=1,James Duckett,Great Children's Book,23-Aug-04,"As an adult, I picked these books up to see if these would be a good book for my child to read. And for a elementary children, this is a wonderful book. The read is relatively quick so they aren't overwhelmed by the thickness and it is still a fun story with characters that you feel terribly bad for.
The prose is perfect for children. It is easy to read and filled with alliteration. Best of all
column2: this book goes out of its way to teach vocabulary to children. Instead of filling the book with long words (for children) expecting the children to look up the words they didn't understand (which they won't)
column3: it goes out of its way to explain the bigger words.

column1: This is the story of the Baudelaire siblings and continues where the first book left off as they are taken to their Uncle Monty's house to be taken care of.  While they begin to love Uncle Monty and look forward to spending a life with him
column2: another scheme is hatched by Count Olaf to take control of the fortune.  Again the only thing that can help the Baudelaire orphans is their wit

column1: You are warned at the beginning of the book
column3: that this book does not have a happy ending. It is part right. The book does not have the best ending
column4: but it doesn't have the worst ending either. I'll pick up the other books
column5: but it does appear that this book will not leave you hanging and wishing for a different ending. Actually
column6: I prefer this ending which shows that not everything will go your way which is the norm in life and not the exception. I don't think elementary school aged children are too young to start learning this

column1: If you have young children (grades 2-6) I would highly recommend you encourage them to read this series. This would be a good step into getting them to like reading. column1: 1556766040-4163,https://www.amazon.com/Carnivorous-Carnival-Unfortunate-Events/product-reviews/0064410129/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_hist_5?ie=UTF8&reviewerType=all_reviews&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=1,Lonnie E. Holder,The Carnivorous Carnival will Eat You Up!,8-May-03,"The Baudelaire orphans left ""The Hostile Hospital"" in the trunk of Count Olaf's car; clearly a potentially very dangerous situation for Violet, Klaus and baby Sunny.  However, once again the children use their wits to figure out how to escape their predicament.

The children find themselves in a run down carnival with another bizarre cast of characters, including several supposed ""freaks.""  However, the freaks are not really all that freakish, one being a contortionist and one being ambidextrous.  The children disguise themselves as freaks and manage to fool Count Olaf and his gang for most of the book.  However, as we all know, eventually Count Olaf finds the children and another harrowing ending ensues.
Over the last two or three books we've been given tidbits about bigger mysteries surrounding the children and their parents.  In this book the tidbits become much more substantial
column2: and give us a clue as to the direction the series might take.  While it may seem that my description is a bit vague
column3: that is because I do not wish to give away any of the surprises in this book
column4: and there is at least one very big surprise for the children and the reader
column5: as well as a number of smaller surprises.

column1: Because of the twists and turns
column2: I am unable to provide the description I normally do for books in this series.  As I noted earlier
column3: there are a lot of surprises.  Those surprises make for one of the most intriguing books in this series.  I am anxiously anticipating the next volume
column6: when I am hoping all the mysteries are finally revealed.

column1: This particular entry in the series does involve death, again, and in your imagination the death is likely somewhat gruesome.  Fortunately the amount of description given to the death is minimal, and is left mostly to the reader's imagination.  Because of several intense moments, and the death, I would recommend this book for children 9 and older, though as always you should know the ability of your child to handle books similar to this one.  This book does have its educational moments, though somewhat muted in comparison to some of the other entries in this series.  Overall, the continued challenge to the paradigm that children's books for the stated age range should be relatively tame along with the creativity of this particular book requires a rating of 5 stars.  Another solid entry in this series, which just seems to get better and better.",5.0 out of 5 stars,Next page?,https://www.amazon.com/Carnivorous-Carnival-Unfortunate-Events/product-reviews/0064410129/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_paging_btm_42?ie=UTF8&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=42&reviewerType=all_reviews

This boxed gift set contains the first three books in hardcover: The Bad Beginning, The Reptile Room, and The Wide Window.
Much tragedy and unfortunate things befall the Baudelaire children
column4: and Sunny. They were on the beach when a family friend
column6: told them that their parents had died in the Baudelaire mansion in a fire. Mr. Poe explained that their parents had instructed that the children be put in the care of a relative
column7: and the fortune would remain untouched until Violet was of legal age. It was decided that they were going to stay with Count Olaf
column8: because he was the relative that lived closest to the Baudelaires' home
column9: so he adopted the children. They all hated him from the moment they met him. Count Olaf was planning ways to gain control over the Baudelaire fortune.

column1: It is so refreshing to find an author who is funny without assuming that kids need potty jokes to laugh. The humor is dark
column3: and hilarious.  While the Baudelaire Orphan's series are written for children
column4: they can still be appreciated by mature readers. You truly root for Violet
column6: and Sonny and feel sadness and anger over their plight. Count Olaf is truly a degenerate villain for whom nothing is too extreme even murdering a child. Very few villains can be so simply crafted yet inspire such revulsion from the reader. Oddly enough this is a feat rarely accomplished by other more widely recognized by the public.

column1: 1556766060-4253,https://www.amazon.com/Carnivorous-Carnival-Unfortunate-Events/product-reviews/0064410129/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_hist_5?ie=UTF8&reviewerType=all_reviews&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=1,Megan Twain,"Nice, but don't I say that about all of them?",4-Aug-05,"The belly of the beast! Freaks! Lemony Snicket! That's all I have to say...............................OK, maybe I could say more. Lemony Snicket hits the mark for a great book....AGAIN. I have to say, they really stick to the story in this series, which pleases me very much. I can 99.9% guarantee the next one will be a hit. Count Olaf is as 'dashing' as ever(aka horrible, smelly, awful, gross, ugly and mean as ever). Very funny, one of the most humorous! And guess what? We're getting closer to learning all of the secrets about V.F.D. *Smiles mysteriously* Seriously, one of the best in the series, but then again, they're ALL the best in the series. *Whines* Can't choose!",5.0 out of 5 stars,Next page?,https://www.amazon.com/Carnivorous-Carnival-Unfortunate-Events/product-reviews/0064410129/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_paging_btm_51?ie=UTF8&filterByStar=five_star&pageNumber=51&reviewerType=all_reviews
